p: As discussed, SARS-CoV-2 employs ACE2 as the host cell receptor. ACE2 is highly expressed on many different cell types in a variety of human organs, including lung alveolar epithelial cells and small intestinal epithelial cells, both of which are considered potential SARS-CoV-2 routes of transmission. Overall, ACE2 is expressed widely in the main target organs of SARS-CoV-2, as well as organs that play less important or even unknown roles in COVID-19 pathophysiology [ 28]. It has been reported that SARS-CoV also infects immune cells such as T lymphocytes, monocytes and macrophages [ 29], but it remains poorly defined as to what extent SARS-CoV-2 also targets these cells. A number of studies are exploring the immune response to the SARS-CoV-2 [ 30], with most suggesting that the immune response is disturbed due to aberrant activation of monocytes/macrophages [ 31], elevation of pro-inflammatory cytokines [ 32], depletion of lymphocytes [ 33] and deployment of large numbers of neutrophils [ 34], but the complex mechanisms involved are still not well understood.
